title: Credit card debt settlement/default: can they force sale of property not in my name?
question: I had to stop working due to disability due to a health condition. I am now receiving disability benefits, but they are a lot less than my previous income. I have run up a lot of credit card debt (aprox 40 thousand) paying bills and medical expenses. I have been paying the minimum monthly payments, but will not be able to afford to do so for much longer. If I stop making payments and attempt to negotiate a settlement, can the credit card companies sue my husband (in addition to myself) ? My husband owns a rental property which he purchased many years before our marriage. Our home is in his name, but the home equity loan is in both of our names. My main concern is whether they could force the sale of either property in order to pay the debt. We live in California.
answers:
His separate rental property your husband acquired before your marriage they could not touch unless they can establish a community property component which is the rare exception for debt collectors in CA. If it was paid for before you were married, then you do not need to worry. They could get a judgment against you and then place a lien against your property so when you sell of refinance the lien has to be satisfied.
